{{Infobox anatomy | Name = Marrow adipose tissue | Latin = | Greek = | Image = Marrow Adipocytes are derived from mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) differentiation.png | Caption = Illustration of [[Mesenchymal stem cell|MSC]] differentiation into [[adipocyte]]s and [[osteoblast]]s | Width = | Image2 = | Caption2 = | Precursor = | System = | Artery = | Vein = | Nerve = | Lymph = }} '''Marrow adipose tissue''' (MAT) , also known as bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT), increases in states of low bone density -[[osteoporosis]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cohen|first=Adi|last2=Dempster|first2=David W.|last3=Stein|first3=Emily M.|last4=Nickolas|first4=Thomas L.|last5=Zhou|first5=Hua|last6=McMahon|first6=Donald J.|last7=Müller|first7=Ralph|last8=Kohler|first8=Thomas|last9=Zwahlen|first9=Alexander|date=August 2012|title=Increased Marrow Adiposity in Premenopausal Women with Idiopathic Osteoporosis|url=|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=97|issue=8|pages=2782–2791|doi=10.1210/jc.2012-1477|issn=0021-972X|pmc=3410269|pmid=22701013|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meunier|first=P.|last2=Aaron|first2=J.|last3=Edouard|first3=C.|last4=Vignon|first4=G.|date=October 1971|title=Osteoporosis and the replacement of cell populations of the marrow by adipose tissue. A quantitative study of 84 iliac bone biopsies|journal=Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research|volume=80|pages=147–154|issn=0009-921X|pmid=5133320}}</ref> [[anorexia nervosa]]/ [[Calorie restriction|caloric restriction]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fazeli|first=Pouneh K.|last2=Horowitz|first2=Mark C.|last3=MacDougald|first3=Ormond A.|last4=Scheller|first4=Erica L.|last5=Rodeheffer|first5=Matthew S.|last6=Rosen|first6=Clifford J.|last7=Klibanski|first7=Anne|date=March 2013|title=Marrow fat and bone--new perspectives|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=98|issue=3|pages=935–945|doi=10.1210/jc.2012-3634|issn=1945-7197|pmc=3590487|pmid=23393168}}</ref> skeletal unweighting,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ahdjoudj|first=Souhila|last2=Lasmoles|first2=Françoise|last3=Holy|first3=Xavier|last4=Zerath|first4=Erik|last5=Marie|first5=Pierre J.|date=April 2002|title=Transforming growth factor beta2 inhibits adipocyte differentiation induced by skeletal unloading in rat bone marrow stroma|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|volume=17|issue=4|pages=668–677|doi=10.1359/jbmr.2002.17.4.668|issn=0884-0431|pmid=11918224}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wronski|first=T. J.|last2=Morey|first2=E. R.|date=1982-01-01|title=Skeletal abnormalities in rats induced by simulated weightlessness|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/022187478290011X|journal=Metabolic Bone Disease and Related Research|volume=4|issue=1|pages=69–75|doi=10.1016/0221-8747(82)90011-X}}</ref> anti-[[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] therapies<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rubin|first=M. R.|last2=Manavalan|first2=J. S.|last3=Agarwal|first3=S.|last4=McMahon|first4=D. J.|last5=Nino|first5=A.|last6=Fitzpatrick|first6=L. A.|last7=Bilezikian|first7=J. P.|date=October 2014|title=Effects of rosiglitazone vs metformin on circulating osteoclast and osteogenic precursor cells in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes mellitus|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=99|issue=10|pages=E1933–1942|doi=10.1210/jc.2013-3666|issn=1945-7197|pmid=24905061}}</ref>). The marrow [[adipocyte]]s originate from [[Mesenchymal stem cell|mesenchymal stem cell (MSC)]] progenitors that also give rise to [[osteoblast]]s, among other cell types.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Muruganandan|first=S.|last2=Roman|first2=A. A.|last3=Sinal|first3=C. J.|date=January 2009|title=Adipocyte differentiation of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells: cross talk with the osteoblastogenic program|journal=Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences: CMLS|volume=66|issue=2|pages=236–253|doi=10.1007/s00018-008-8429-z|issn=1420-9071|pmid=18854943}}</ref> Thus, it is thought that MAT results from preferential [[Mesenchymal stem cell|MSC]] differentiation into the [[adipocyte]], rather than osteoblast, lineage in the setting of osteoporosis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paccou|first=Julien|last2=Hardouin|first2=Pierre|last3=Cotten|first3=Anne|last4=Penel|first4=Guillaume|last5=Cortet|first5=Bernard|date=October 2015|title=The Role of Bone Marrow Fat in Skeletal Health: Usefulness and Perspectives for Clinicians|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=100|issue=10|pages=3613–3621|doi=10.1210/jc.2015-2338|issn=1945-7197|pmid=26244490}}</ref> Since MAT is increased in the setting of obesity<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Styner|first=Maya|last2=Thompson|first2=William R.|last3=Galior|first3=Kornelia|last4=Uzer|first4=Gunes|last5=Wu|first5=Xin|last6=Kadari|first6=Sanjay|last7=Case|first7=Natasha|last8=Xie|first8=Zhihui|last9=Sen|first9=Buer|date=July 2014|title=Bone marrow fat accumulation accelerated by high fat diet is suppressed by exercise|journal=Bone|volume=64|pages=39–46|doi=10.1016/j.bone.2014.03.044|issn=1873-2763|pmc=4041820|pmid=24709686}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Scheller|first=Erica L.|last2=Khoury|first2=Basma|last3=Moller|first3=Kayla L.|last4=Wee|first4=Natalie K. Y.|last5=Khandaker|first5=Shaima|last6=Kozloff|first6=Kenneth M.|last7=Abrishami|first7=Simin H.|last8=Zamarron|first8=Brian F.|last9=Singer|first9=Kanakadurga|date=2016|title=Changes in Skeletal Integrity and Marrow Adiposity during High-Fat Diet and after Weight Loss|journal=Frontiers in Endocrinology|volume=7|pages=102|doi=10.3389/fendo.2016.00102|pmc=4961699|pmid=27512386}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Doucette|first=Casey R.|last2=Horowitz|first2=Mark C.|last3=Berry|first3=Ryan|last4=MacDougald|first4=Ormond A.|last5=Anunciado-Koza|first5=Rea|last6=Koza|first6=Robert A.|last7=Rosen|first7=Clifford J.|date=September 2015|title=A High Fat Diet Increases Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue (MAT) But Does Not Alter Trabecular or Cortical Bone Mass in C57BL/6J Mice|journal=Journal of Cellular Physiology|volume=230|issue=9|pages=2032–2037|doi=10.1002/jcp.24954|issn=1097-4652|pmc=4580244|pmid=25663195}}</ref> and is suppressed by endurance exercise,<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Styner|first=Maya|last2=Pagnotti|first2=Gabriel M.|last3=Galior|first3=Kornelia|last4=Wu|first4=Xin|last5=Thompson|first5=William R.|last6=Uzer|first6=Gunes|last7=Sen|first7=Buer|last8=Xie|first8=Zhihui|last9=Horowitz|first9=Mark C.|date=August 2015|title=Exercise Regulation of Marrow Fat in the Setting of PPARγ Agonist Treatment in Female C57BL/6 Mice|journal=Endocrinology|volume=156|issue=8|pages=2753–2761|doi=10.1210/en.2015-1213|issn=1945-7170|pmc=4511140|pmid=26052898}}</ref><ref name=":1"/><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Styner|first=Maya|last2=Pagnotti|first2=Gabriel M|last3=McGrath|first3=Cody|last4=Wu|first4=Xin|last5=Sen|first5=Buer|last6=Uzer|first6=Gunes|last7=Xie|first7=Zhihui|last8=Zong|first8=Xiaopeng|last9=Styner|first9=Martin A|date=2017-05-01|title=Exercise Decreases Marrow Adipose Tissue Through ß-Oxidation in Obese Running Mice|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|volume=32|issue=8|language=en|pages=1692–1702|doi=10.1002/jbmr.3159|pmid=28436105|pmc=5550355|issn=1523-4681}}</ref> or [[vibration]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Luu|first=Yen K.|last2=Pessin|first2=Jeffrey E.|last3=Judex|first3=Stefan|last4=Rubin|first4=Janet|last5=Rubin|first5=Clinton T.|date=April 2009|title=Mechanical signals as a non-invasive means to influence mesenchymal stem cell fate, promoting bone and suppressing the fat phenotype|url=http://www.nature.com/bonekey/knowledgeenvironment/2009/0904/bonekey20090371/full/bonekey20090371.html?foxtrotcallback=true|journal=IBMS BoneKEy|language=en|volume=6|issue=4|pages=132–149|doi=10.1138/20090371|pmc=3255555|pmid=22241295}}</ref> it is likely that MAT physiology- in the setting of mechanical input/exercise- approximates that of [[white adipose tissue]] (WAT). The first study to demonstrate exercise regulation of MAT in rodents was published in 2014;<ref name=":1" /> now, exercise regulation of MAT has been confirmed in a human study as well<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Belavy|first=Daniel L.|last2=Quittner|first2=Matthew J.|last3=Ridgers|first3=Nicola D.|last4=Shiekh|first4=Adnan|last5=Rantalainen|first5=Timo|last6=Trudel|first6=Guy|date=2018-01-16|title=Specific Modulation of Vertebral Marrow Adipose Tissue by Physical Activity|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|volume=33|issue=4|pages=651–657|doi=10.1002/jbmr.3357|issn=1523-4681|pmid=29336053}}</ref> adding clinical significance to this work.
MAT has qualities of both [[White adipose tissue|white]] and [[Brown adipose tissue|brown]] fat.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Krings|first=A.|last2=Rahman|first2=S.|last3=Huang|first3=S.|last4=Lu|first4=Y.|last5=Czernik|first5=P. J.|last6=Lecka-Czernik|first6=B.|date=February 2012|title=Bone marrow fat has brown adipose tissue characteristics, which are attenuated with aging and diabetes|journal=Bone|volume=50|issue=2|pages=546–552|doi=10.1016/j.bone.2011.06.016|issn=1873-2763|pmc=3214232|pmid=21723971}}</ref> [[Subcutaneous adipose tissue|Subcutaneous white fat]] contain excess energy, indicating a clear evolutionary advantage during times of scarcity. [[White adipose tissue|WAT]] is also the source of adipokines and inflammatory markers which have both positive (e.g., [[adiponectin]])<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ye|first=Risheng|last2=Scherer|first2=Philipp E.|date=2013-04-19|title=Adiponectin, driver or passenger on the road to insulin sensitivity?|journal=Molecular Metabolism|volume=2|issue=3|pages=133–141|doi=10.1016/j.molmet.2013.04.001|issn=2212-8778|pmc=3773837|pmid=24049728}}</ref> and negative<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tilg|first=Herbert|last2=Moschen|first2=Alexander R.|date=October 2006|title=Adipocytokines: mediators linking adipose tissue, inflammation and immunity|journal=Nature Reviews. Immunology|volume=6|issue=10|pages=772–783|doi=10.1038/nri1937|issn=1474-1733|pmid=16998510}}</ref> effects on metabolic and cardiovascular endpoints. [[Visceral adiposity|Visceral abdominal fat]] (VAT) is a distinct type of WAT that is "proportionally associated with negative metabolic and cardiovascular morbidity",<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wronska|first=A.|last2=Kmiec|first2=Z.|date=June 2012|title=Structural and biochemical characteristics of various white adipose tissue depots|journal=Acta Physiologica|volume=205|issue=2|pages=194–208|doi=10.1111/j.1748-1716.2012.02409.x|issn=1748-1716|pmid=22226221}}</ref> regenerates cortisol,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Masuzaki|first=H.|last2=Paterson|first2=J.|last3=Shinyama|first3=H.|last4=Morton|first4=N. M.|last5=Mullins|first5=J. J.|last6=Seckl|first6=J. R.|last7=Flier|first7=J. S.|date=2001-12-07|title=A transgenic model of visceral obesity and the metabolic syndrome|journal=Science|volume=294|issue=5549|pages=2166–2170|doi=10.1126/science.1066285|issn=0036-8075|pmid=11739957}}</ref> and recently has been tied to decreased bone formation<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bredella|first=Miriam A.|last2=Lin|first2=Eleanor|last3=Gerweck|first3=Anu V.|last4=Landa|first4=Melissa G.|last5=Thomas|first5=Bijoy J.|last6=Torriani|first6=Martin|last7=Bouxsein|first7=Mary L.|last8=Miller|first8=Karen K.|date=November 2012|title=Determinants of bone microarchitecture and mechanical properties in obese men|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=97|issue=11|pages=4115–4122|doi=10.1210/jc.2012-2246|issn=1945-7197|pmc=3485587|pmid=22933540}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cohen|first=Adi|last2=Dempster|first2=David W.|last3=Recker|first3=Robert R.|last4=Lappe|first4=Joan M.|last5=Zhou|first5=Hua|last6=Zwahlen|first6=Alexander|last7=Müller|first7=Ralph|last8=Zhao|first8=Binsheng|last9=Guo|first9=Xiaotao|date=June 2013|title=Abdominal fat is associated with lower bone formation and inferior bone quality in healthy premenopausal women: a transiliac bone biopsy study|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=98|issue=6|pages=2562–2572|doi=10.1210/jc.2013-1047|issn=1945-7197|pmc=3667251|pmid=23515452}}</ref> Both types of [[White adipose tissue|WAT]] substantially differ from [[Brown adipose tissue|brown adipose tissue (BAT)]] as by a group of proteins that help BAT’s [[Thermogenesis|thermogenic]] role.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wu|first=Jun|last2=Cohen|first2=Paul|last3=Spiegelman|first3=Bruce M.|date=2013-02-01|title=Adaptive thermogenesis in adipocytes: is beige the new brown?|journal=Genes & Development|volume=27|issue=3|pages=234–250|doi=10.1101/gad.211649.112|issn=1549-5477|pmc=3576510|pmid=23388824}}</ref> MAT, by its "specific [[Bone marrow|marrow]] location, and its adipocyte origin from at least [[Leptin receptor|LepR]]+ marrow MSC is separated from non-bone fat storage by larger expression of bone transcription factors",<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Al-Nbaheen|first=May|last2=vishnubalaji|first2=Radhakrishnan|last3=Ali|first3=Dalia|last4=Bouslimi|first4=Amel|last5=Al-Jassir|first5=Fawzi|last6=Megges|first6=Matthias|last7=Prigione|first7=Alessandro|last8=Adjaye|first8=James|last9=Kassem|first9=Moustapha|date=February 2013|title=Human Stromal (Mesenchymal) Stem Cells from Bone Marrow, Adipose Tissue and Skin Exhibit Differences in Molecular Phenotype and Differentiation Potential|url=|journal=Stem Cell Reviews|volume=9|issue=1|pages=32–43|doi=10.1007/s12015-012-9365-8|issn=1550-8943|pmc=3563956|pmid=22529014|via=}}</ref> and likely indicates a different fat phenotype.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gimble|first=Jeffrey M.|last2=Zvonic|first2=Sanjin|last3=Floyd|first3=Z. Elizabeth|last4=Kassem|first4=Moustapha|last5=Nuttall|first5=Mark E.|date=2006-05-15|title=Playing with bone and fat|journal=Journal of Cellular Biochemistry|volume=98|issue=2|pages=251–266|doi=10.1002/jcb.20777|issn=0730-2312|pmid=16479589}}</ref> Recently, MAT was noted to "produce a greater proportion of [[adiponectin]] - an adipokine associated with improved metabolism - than [[White adipose tissue|WAT]]",<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cawthorn|first=William P.|last2=Scheller|first2=Erica L.|last3=Learman|first3=Brian S.|last4=Parlee|first4=Sebastian D.|last5=Simon|first5=Becky R.|last6=Mori|first6=Hiroyuki|last7=Ning|first7=Xiaomin|last8=Bree|first8=Adam J.|last9=Schell|first9=Benjamin|date=2014-08-05|title=Bone marrow adipose tissue is an endocrine organ that contributes to increased circulating adiponectin during caloric restriction|journal=Cell Metabolism|volume=20|issue=2|pages=368–375|doi=10.1016/j.cmet.2014.06.003|issn=1932-7420|pmc=4126847|pmid=24998914}}</ref> suggesting an endocrine function for this depot, akin, but different, from that of [[White adipose tissue|WAT]].
== Marrow Adipose Tissue (MAT) and Bone Health == MAT increases in states of bone fragility. MAT is thought to result from preferential MSC differentiation into an adipocyte, rather than osteoblast lineage in [[osteoporosis]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paccou|first=Julien|last2=Hardouin|first2=Pierre|last3=Cotten|first3=Anne|last4=Penel|first4=Guillaume|last5=Cortet|first5=Bernard|date=2015-10-01|title=The Role of Bone Marrow Fat in Skeletal Health: Usefulness and Perspectives for Clinicians|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/100/10/3613/2835766/The-Role-of-Bone-Marrow-Fat-in-Skeletal-Health|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism|volume=100|issue=10|pages=3613–3621|doi=10.1210/jc.2015-2338|pmid=26244490|issn=0021-972X}}</ref> based on the inverse relationship between bone and MAT in bone-fragile osteoporotic states. An increase in MAT is noted in osteoporosis clinical studies measured by [[MR Spectroscopy]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Duque|first=G.|last2=Li|first2=W.|last3=Adams|first3=M.|last4=Xu|first4=S.|last5=Phipps|first5=R.|date=2011-05-01|title=Effects of risedronate on bone marrow adipocytes in postmenopausal women|journal=Osteoporosis International|language=en|volume=22|issue=5|pages=1547–1553|doi=10.1007/s00198-010-1353-8|pmid=20661545|issn=0937-941X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yeung|first=David K. W.|last2=Griffith|first2=James F.|last3=Antonio|first3=Gregory E.|last4=Lee|first4=Francis K. H.|last5=Woo|first5=Jean|last6=Leung|first6=Ping C.|date=August 2005|title=Osteoporosis is associated with increased marrow fat content and decreased marrow fat unsaturation: a proton MR spectroscopy study|journal=Journal of Magnetic Resonance Imaging: JMRI|volume=22|issue=2|pages=279–285|doi=10.1002/jmri.20367|issn=1053-1807|pmid=16028245}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=Xiaojuan|last2=Kuo|first2=Daniel|last3=Schafer|first3=Anne L.|last4=Porzig|first4=Anne|last5=Link|first5=Thomas M.|last6=Black|first6=Dennis|last7=Schwartz|first7=Ann V.|date=2011-04-01|title=Quantification of vertebral bone marrow fat content using 3 tesla MR spectroscopy: Reproducibility, vertebral variation, and applications in osteoporosis|journal=Journal of Magnetic Resonance Imaging|language=en|volume=33|issue=4|pages=974–979|doi=10.1002/jmri.22489|issn=1522-2586|pmc=3072841|pmid=21448966}}</ref> [[Hormone replacement therapy (menopause)|Estrogen]] therapy in [[postmenopausal osteoporosis]] reduces MAT.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Syed|first=F. A.|last2=Oursler|first2=M. J.|last3=Hefferanm|first3=T. E.|last4=Peterson|first4=J. M.|last5=Riggs|first5=B. L.|last6=Khosla|first6=S.|date=2008-09-01|title=Effects of estrogen therapy on bone marrow adipocytes in postmenopausal osteoporotic women|journal=Osteoporosis International|language=en|volume=19|issue=9|pages=1323–1330|doi=10.1007/s00198-008-0574-6|issn=0937-941X|pmc=2652842|pmid=18274695}}</ref> Antiresorptive therapies like [[risedronate]] or [[Zoledronic acid|zoledronate]] also decrease MAT while increasing bone density, supporting an inverse relationship between bone quantity and MAT. During aging, bone quantity declines<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Khosla|first=Sundeep|last2=Riggs|first2=B Lawrence|last3=Atkinson|first3=Elizabeth J|last4=Oberg|first4=Ann L|last5=McDaniel|first5=Lisa J|last6=Holets|first6=Margaret|last7=Peterson|first7=James M|last8=Melton|first8=L Joseph|date=2006-01-01|title=Effects of Sex and Age on Bone Microstructure at the Ultradistal Radius: A Population-Based Noninvasive In Vivo Assessment|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=21|issue=1|pages=124–131|doi=10.1359/jbmr.050916|pmid=16355281|issn=1523-4681|pmc=1352156}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Glatt|first=Vaida|last2=Canalis|first2=Ernesto|last3=Stadmeyer|first3=Lisa|last4=Bouxsein|first4=Mary L|date=2007-08-01|title=Age-Related Changes in Trabecular Architecture Differ in Female and Male C57BL/6J Mice|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=22|issue=8|pages=1197–1207|doi=10.1359/jbmr.070507|pmid=17488199|issn=1523-4681}}</ref> and fat redistributes from subcutaneous to [[mwod:ectopic|ectopic]] sites such as [[bone marrow]], muscle, and liver.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tchkonia|first=Tamara|last2=Morbeck|first2=Dean E.|last3=Von Zglinicki|first3=Thomas|last4=Van Deursen|first4=Jan|last5=Lustgarten|first5=Joseph|last6=Scrable|first6=Heidi|last7=Khosla|first7=Sundeep|last8=Jensen|first8=Michael D.|last9=Kirkland|first9=James L.|date=2010-10-01|title=Fat tissue, aging, and cellular senescence|journal=Aging Cell|language=en|volume=9|issue=5|pages=667–684|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9726.2010.00608.x|issn=1474-9726|pmc=2941545|pmid=20701600}}</ref> [[Aging]] is associated with lower osteogenic and greater adipogenic biasing of MSC.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kassem|first=Moustapha|last2=Marie|first2=Pierre J.|date=2011-04-01|title=Senescence-associated intrinsic mechanisms of osteoblast dysfunctions|journal=Aging Cell|language=en|volume=10|issue=2|pages=191–197|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9726.2011.00669.x|pmid=21210937|issn=1474-9726}}</ref> This aging-related biasing of MSC away from osteoblast lineage may represent higher basal [[Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma|PPARγ]] expression<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moerman|first=Elena J.|last2=Teng|first2=Kui|last3=Lipschitz|first3=David A.|last4=Lecka-Czernik|first4=Beata|date=2004-12-01|title=Aging activates adipogenic and suppresses osteogenic programs in mesenchymal marrow stroma/stem cells: the role of PPAR-γ2 transcription factor and TGF-β/BMP signaling pathways|journal=Aging Cell|language=en|volume=3|issue=6|pages=379–389|doi=10.1111/j.1474-9728.2004.00127.x|issn=1474-9726|pmc=1850101|pmid=15569355}}</ref> or decreased Wnt10b.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stevens|first=Jennifer R|last2=Miranda-Carboni|first2=Gustavo A|last3=Singer|first3=Meredith A|last4=Brugger|first4=Sean M|last5=Lyons|first5=Karen M|last6=Lane|first6=Timothy F|date=2010-10-01|title=Wnt10b deficiency results in age-dependent loss of bone mass and progressive reduction of mesenchymal progenitor cells|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=25|issue=10|pages=2138–2147|doi=10.1002/jbmr.118|issn=1523-4681|pmc=3153316|pmid=20499361}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bennett|first=Christina N|last2=Ouyang|first2=Hongjiao|last3=Ma|first3=Yanfei L|last4=Zeng|first4=Qingqiang|last5=Gerin|first5=Isabelle|last6=Sousa|first6=Kyle M|last7=Lane|first7=Timothy F|last8=Krishnan|first8=Venkatesh|last9=Hankenson|first9=Kurt D|date=2007-12-01|title=Wnt10b Increases Postnatal Bone Formation by Enhancing Osteoblast Differentiation|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=22|issue=12|pages=1924–1932|doi=10.1359/jbmr.070810|pmid=17708715|issn=1523-4681}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=Q.|last2=Shou|first2=P.|last3=Zheng|first3=C.|last4=Jiang|first4=M.|last5=Cao|first5=G.|last6=Yang|first6=Q.|last7=Cao|first7=J.|last8=Xie|first8=N.|last9=Velletri|first9=T.|date=July 2016|title=Fate decision of mesenchymal stem cells: adipocytes or osteoblasts?|url=http://www.nature.com/cdd/journal/v23/n7/full/cdd2015168a.html|journal=Cell Death & Differentiation|language=en|volume=23|issue=7|pages=1128–1139|doi=10.1038/cdd.2015.168|issn=1350-9047|pmc=4946886|pmid=26868907}}</ref> Thus, bone fragility, osteoporosis, and osteoporotic fractures are thought to be linked to mechanisms which promote MAT accumulation.
<gallery class="center" caption="Histologic sections demonstrating Marrow Adipocytes" widths="300" heights="300" classes="center"> File:Marrow Adipose Tissue (typical quantity young mouse) cropped.jpg|Representative distal femur histologic section of a 16-week old healthy C57BL/6 mouse demonstrating a typical quantity of marrow adipocytes. File:Increased Marrow Adipose Tissue cropped.jpg|Representative distal femur histologic section of a 16-week old C57BL/6 mouse after 6 weeks of calorie restriction demonstrating an increased quantity of marrow adipocytes. </gallery>
== Measurement of Marrow Adipose Tissue == In order to understand the physiology of MAT, various analytic methods have been applied. Marrow adipocytes are difficult to isolate and quantify because they are interspersed with bony and [[hematopoietic]] elements. Until recently, qualitative measurements of MAT have relied on bone [[histology]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bielohuby|first=Maximilian|last2=Matsuura|first2=Maiko|last3=Herbach|first3=Nadja|last4=Kienzle|first4=Ellen|last5=Slawik|first5=Marc|last6=Hoeflich|first6=Andreas|last7=Bidlingmaier|first7=Martin|date=2010-02-01|title=Short-term exposure to low-carbohydrate, high-fat diets induces low bone mineral density and reduces bone formation in rats|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=25|issue=2|pages=275–284|doi=10.1359/jbmr.090813|pmid=19653818|issn=1523-4681}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spatz|first=Jordan M|last2=Ellman|first2=Rachel|last3=Cloutier|first3=Alison M|last4=Louis|first4=Leeann|last5=van Vliet|first5=Miranda|last6=Suva|first6=Larry J|last7=Dwyer|first7=Denise|last8=Stolina|first8=Marina|last9=Ke|first9=Hua Zhu|date=2013-04-01|title=Sclerostin antibody inhibits skeletal deterioration due to reduced mechanical loading|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=865–874|doi=10.1002/jbmr.1807|issn=1523-4681|pmc=4076162|pmid=23109229}}</ref> which is subject to site [[selection bias]] and cannot adequately quantify the volume of fat in the marrow. Nevertheless, histological techniques and fixation make possible visualization of MAT, quantification of adipocyte size, and MAT’s association with the surrounding [[endosteum]], milieu of cells, and secreted factors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosen|first=Clifford J.|last2=Ackert-Bicknell|first2=Cheryl L.|last3=Adamo|first3=Martin L.|last4=Shultz|first4=Kathy L.|last5=Rubin|first5=Janet|last6=Donahue|first6=Leah Rae|last7=Horton|first7=Lindsay G.|last8=Delahunty|first8=Krista M.|last9=Beamer|first9=Wesley G.|title=Congenic mice with low serum IGF-I have increased body fat, reduced bone mineral density, and an altered osteoblast differentiation program|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S8756328204003023|journal=Bone|volume=35|issue=5|pages=1046–1058|doi=10.1016/j.bone.2004.07.008|pmid=15542029|year=2004}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Naveiras|first=Olaia|last2=Nardi|first2=Valentina|last3=Wenzel|first3=Pamela L.|last4=Hauschka|first4=Peter V.|last5=Fahey|first5=Frederic|last6=Daley|first6=George Q.|title=Bone-marrow adipocytes as negative regulators of the haematopoietic microenvironment|journal=Nature|volume=460|issue=7252|pages=259–263|doi=10.1038/nature08099|pmc=2831539|pmid=19516257|year=2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Valentin|last2=Martin|first2=Aline|last3=Lafage-Proust|first3=Marie-Hélène|last4=Malaval|first4=Luc|last5=Peyroche|first5=Sylvie|last6=Jones|first6=David B.|last7=Vico|first7=Laurence|last8=Guignandon|first8=Alain|date=2007-05-01|title=Mechanical Loading Down-Regulates Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptor γ in Bone Marrow Stromal Cells and Favors Osteoblastogenesis at the Expense of Adipogenesis|url=https://academic.oup.com/endo/article/148/5/2553/2502450/Mechanical-Loading-Down-Regulates-Peroxisome|journal=Endocrinology|volume=148|issue=5|pages=2553–2562|doi=10.1210/en.2006-1704|pmid=17317771|issn=0013-7227}}</ref>
Recent advances in cell surface and intracellular marker identification and single-cell analyses led to greater resolution and high-throughput ''ex-vivo'' quantification. [[Flow cytometry|Flow cytometric]] quantification can be used to purify adipocytes from the stromal vascular fraction of most fat depots.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Majka|first=Susan M.|last2=Miller|first2=Heidi L.|last3=Sullivan|first3=Timothy|last4=Erickson|first4=Paul F.|last5=Kong|first5=Raymond|last6=Weiser-Evans|first6=Mary|last7=Nemenoff|first7=Raphael|last8=Moldovan|first8=Radu|last9=Morandi|first9=Shelley A.|date=2012-10-01|title=Adipose lineage specification of bone marrow-derived myeloid cells|journal=Adipocyte|volume=1|issue=4|pages=215–229|doi=10.4161/adip.21496|issn=2162-3945|pmc=3609111|pmid=23700536}}</ref> Early research with such machinery cited adipocytes as too large and fragile for cytometer-based purification, rendering them susceptible to lysis; however, recent advances have been made to mitigate this;<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/B978012411619100015X|last=Majka|first=Susan M.|last2=Miller|first2=Heidi L.|last3=Helm|first3=Karen M.|last4=Acosta|first4=Alistaire S.|last5=Childs|first5=Christine R.|last6=Kong|first6=Raymond|last7=Klemm|first7=Dwight J.|pages=281–296|doi=10.1016/b978-0-12-411619-1.00015-x|pmid=24480352|pmc=4143162|title=Methods of Adipose Tissue Biology, Part A|volume=537|series=Methods in Enzymology|year=2014|isbn=9780124116191}}</ref> nevertheless, this methodology continues to pose technical challenges<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bernstein|first=R. L.|last2=Hyun|first2=William C.|last3=Davis|first3=Jonathan H.|last4=Fulwyler|first4=Mack J.|last5=Pershadsingh|first5=Harrihar A.|date=1989-07-01|title=Flow cytometric analysis of mature adipocytes|journal=Cytometry|language=en|volume=10|issue=4|pages=469–474|doi=10.1002/cyto.990100416|pmid=2766892|issn=1097-0320}}</ref> and is inaccessible to much of the research community.
To improve quantification of MAT, novel [[Medical imaging|imaging]] techniques have been developed as a means to visualize and quantify MAT. Although [[Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy|proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS)]] has been used with success to quantify vertebral MAT in humans,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bredella|first=Miriam A.|last2=Torriani|first2=Martin|last3=Ghomi|first3=Reza Hosseini|last4=Thomas|first4=Bijoy J.|last5=Brick|first5=Danielle J.|last6=Gerweck|first6=Anu V.|last7=Rosen|first7=Clifford J.|last8=Klibanski|first8=Anne|last9=Miller|first9=Karen K.|date=2011-01-01|title=Vertebral Bone Marrow Fat Is Positively Associated With Visceral Fat and Inversely Associated With IGF-1 in Obese Women|journal=Obesity|language=en|volume=19|issue=1|pages=49–53|doi=10.1038/oby.2010.106|issn=1930-739X|pmc=3593350|pmid=20467419}}</ref> it is difficult to employ in laboratory animals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Paula|first=Francisco J. A. de|last2=Dick-de-Paula|first2=Ingrid|last3=Bornstein|first3=Sheila|last4=Rostama|first4=Bahman|last5=Le|first5=Phuong|last6=Lotinun|first6=Sutada|last7=Baron|first7=Roland|last8=Rosen|first8=Clifford J.|date=2011-09-01|title=VDR Haploinsufficiency Impacts Body Composition and Skeletal Acquisition in a Gender-Specific Manner|journal=Calcified Tissue International|language=en|volume=89|issue=3|pages=179–191|doi=10.1007/s00223-011-9505-1|issn=0171-967X|pmc=3157554|pmid=21637996}}</ref> [[Magnetic resonance imaging|Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)]] provides MAT assessment in the [[Vertebral column|vertebral skeleton]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fazeli|first=Pouneh K|last2=Bredella|first2=Miriam A|last3=Freedman|first3=Lauren|last4=Thomas|first4=Bijoy J|last5=Breggia|first5=Anne|last6=Meenaghan|first6=Erinne|last7=Rosen|first7=Clifford J|last8=Klibanski|first8=Anne|date=2012-09-01|title=Marrow fat and preadipocyte factor-1 levels decrease with recovery in women with anorexia nervosa|journal=Journal of Bone and Mineral Research|language=en|volume=27|issue=9|pages=1864–1871|doi=10.1002/jbmr.1640|issn=1523-4681|pmc=3415584|pmid=22508185}}</ref> in conjunction with [[X-ray microtomography|μCT]]-based marrow density measurements.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rantalainen|first=Timo|last2=Nikander|first2=Riku|last3=Heinonen|first3=Ari|last4=Cervinka|first4=Tomas|last5=Sievänen|first5=Harri|last6=Daly|first6=Robin M.|date=2013-05-01|title=Differential Effects of Exercise on Tibial Shaft Marrow Density in Young Female Athletes|url=https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/98/5/2037/2537014/Differential-Effects-of-Exercise-on-Tibial-Shaft|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism|volume=98|issue=5|pages=2037–2044|doi=10.1210/jc.2012-3748|pmid=23616150|issn=0021-972X}}</ref> A volumetric method to identify, quantify, and localize MAT in rodent bone has been recently developed, requiring [[osmium]] staining of bones and [[X-ray microtomography|μCT]] imaging,<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/B9780124116191000070|last=Scheller|first=Erica L.|last2=Troiano|first2=Nancy|last3=VanHoutan|first3=Joshua N.|last4=Bouxsein|first4=Mary A.|last5=Fretz|first5=Jackie A.|last6=Xi|first6=Yougen|last7=Nelson|first7=Tracy|last8=Katz|first8=Griffin|last9=Berry|first9=Ryan|pages=123–139|doi=10.1016/b978-0-12-411619-1.00007-0|pmid=24480344|pmc=4097010|title=Methods of Adipose Tissue Biology, Part A|volume=537|series=Methods in Enzymology|year=2014|isbn=9780124116191}}</ref> followed by advanced [[image analysis]] of osmium-bound lipid volume (in mm<sup>3</sup>) relative to bone volume.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> This technique provides reproducible quantification and visualization of MAT, enabling the ability to consistently quantify changes in MAT with diet, exercise, and agents that constrain precursor lineage allocation. Although the osmium method is quantitatively precise, osmium is toxic and cannot be compared across batched experiments. Recently, researchers developed and validated<ref name=":0" /> a 9.4T MRI scanner technique that allows localization and volumetric (3D) quantification that can be compared across experiments. <gallery class="center" caption="Methods for Quantification of Marrow Adipose Tissue (MAT)" widths="400" heights="350" classes="center"> File:Demonstration of Method- Osmium-μCT with Advanced Image Processing.tif|alt=Demonstration of Osmium-μCT method with Advanced Image Processing|Figure. This figure demonstrates the use of the osmium- μCT method with advanced image processing to quantify MAT. In this figure, running exercise is shown to suppress MAT despite PPARγ agonist. Fat binder osmium is imaged via μCT (A ) in n =5 per group overlaid images. Quantification of osmium as MAT/ bone volume in the whole femur is shown. a, significant due to Rosi. b, significant due to exercise. Rosi=rosiglizaone, CTL=control, E=exercise. File:MRI method copy.tif|alt=MRI with image processing as a method to quantify MAT.|Figure. This demonstrates the use of MRI imaging (9.4T scanner) along with advanced image processing to quantify MAT. The images and graph demonstrate that MAT is higher in obese compared with lean mice. B6 mice were fed HFD from age 4 wk until age 16 wk. MAT was quantified by MRI. A) n=10 superimposed group average images are shown B) MAT normalized to bone volume in each group. </gallery>
== Marrow Adipose Tissue and Hematopoietic Cells == [[Hematopoietic]] cells (also known as blood cells) reside in the bone marrow along with marrow adipocytes. These hematopoietic cells are derived from [[hematopoietic stem cell]]s (HSC) which give rise to diverse cells: cells of the blood, immune system, as well as cells that break down bone ([[osteoclast]]s). HSC renewal occurs in the marrow [[Stem-cell niche|stem cell nich]]<nowiki/>e, a microenvironment that contains cells and secreted factors that promote appropriate renewal and differentiation of HSC. The study of the [[Stem-cell niche|stem cell niche]] is relevant to the field of [[oncology]] in order to improve therapy for multiple [[hematologic cancer]]s. As such cancers are often treated with [[bone marrow transplantation]], there is interest in improving the renewal of HSC. Recent work demonstrates that marrow adipocytes secrete factors that promote HSC renewal in most bones.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zhou|first=Bo O.|last2=Yu|first2=Hua|last3=Yue|first3=Rui|last4=Zhao|first4=Zhiyu|last5=Rios|first5=Jonathan J.|last6=Naveiras|first6=Olaia|last7=Morrison|first7=Sean J.|title=Bone marrow adipocytes promote the regeneration of stem cells and haematopoiesis by secreting SCF|journal=Nature Cell Biology|volume=19|issue=8|pages=891–903|doi=10.1038/ncb3570|pmid=28714970|pmc=5536858|year=2017}}</ref>
== References == {{CC-notice|cc=by4|url=http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fendo.2016.00094/full|author(s)=Gabriel M. Pagnotti and Maya Styner}} {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:Nanodumbbels spinning - 01.png|thumb|Illustration of nanodumbbells spinning in a vacuum]] A '''nanodumbell''' is a pair of spheres attached together that may be made of silica or zinc oxide.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s10854-014-2470-5 |title=Investigation on the influence of dichromate ion on the ZnO nano-dumbbells and ZnCr2O4 nano-walls |journal=Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Electronics |volume=26 |issue=2 |pages=821–829 |year=2014 |last1=Dixit |first1=Tejendra |last2=Palani |first2=I. A |last3=Singh |first3=Vipul }}</ref>
They have been used in a [[Purdue University]] experiment where they were made to spin in a vacuum at 60 billion rotations per minute.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/63139-fastest-spinner-nanodumbbell.html|title=What in the Whirled? Tiny, Floating Dumbbell Rotates 60 Billion Times Per Minute|work=Live Science|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>
==Description== The nanodumbbells are first created in the lab using a hydro-thermal process. The resulting dumbbell consists of two joined silica spheres, making it 320 nanometers long and around 170 nanometers wide in size.<ref name=":0" />
Nanodumbbells are also being studied for possible use in [[photodynamic therapy]], a way of treating cancer.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jcis.2017.01.053 |pmid=28167424 |title=Construction of near infrared light triggered nanodumbbell for cancer photodynamic therapy |journal=Journal of Colloid and Interface Science |volume=494 |pages=363–372 |year=2017 |last1=Hou |first1=Beibei |last2=Zheng |first2=Bin |last3=Yang |first3=Weitao |last4=Dong |first4=Chunhong |last5=Wang |first5=Hanjie |last6=Chang |first6=Jin }}</ref>
==Experiment== Highly focused circularly polarized light laser light bombards the levitated dumbbell to set it spinning.<ref name=":0" />
==Previous records== The speed of the rotation is a world record that beats previous records. In 2008, a small motor rotated at 1 million rotations per minute. In 2010, a slice of graphene was made to spin at 60 million spins per minute. Around 2013, a sphere measuring just 4 micrometers was spun at 600 million spins per minute.<ref name=":0" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.livescience.com/63139-fastest-spinner-nanodumbbell.html Image] of the dumbbells *{{cite journal |doi=10.1155/2017/1728345 |title=Effect of Surfactant on Growth of ZnO Nanodumbbells and Their Characterization |journal=Journal of Chemistry |volume=2017 |pages=1–7 |year=2017 |last1=Eadi |first1=Sunil Babu |last2=Kim |first2=Sungjin |last3=Jeong |first3=Soon Wook }}

revision.text:
The '''National Radiological Protection Board''' (NRPB) was a [[public authority]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] created by the Radiological Protection Act 1970. Its statutory functions were to conduct research on radiological protection and provide advice and information on the subject to Government Departments and others. It was also authorized to provide technical services and charge for them. Originally NRPB dealt only with [[ionizing radiation]], but its functions were extended in 1974 to [[non-ionizing radiation]].
==Structure==
The Board consisted of a chairman and a maximum of nine other members, later increased to twelve, all appointed by Health Ministers. Throughout its existence, NRPB had 300 members of staff on average. They were located at the headquarters in [[Chilton, Oxfordshire|Chilton]] near [[Oxford]] and at laboratories in [[Leeds]] and [[Glasgow]]. The [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] funded the difference between the cost of NRPB and its income by annual grant.
==Work==
Research on ionizing radiation included: [[plutonium]] exposure; [[internal dosimetry]]; radioactive discharges; [[nuclear accident]]s and [[Nuclear waste|wastes]]; [[radon]] hazards; medical x rays; [[epidemiology]] and [[molecular biology]]. Research on non-ionizing radiation included the physics and biology of exposure to [[Ultraviolet radiation|ultraviolet sources]], [[electricity]] supplies, and [[mobile phone]]s.
As well as a full range of technical services - from personnel dosimetry to radiation surveys - NRPB also engaged in projects such as: the safe transport of [[radioactive material]]s; preparedness for nuclear emergencies; exposure to [[cosmic ray]]s; optimization of protection; improved radiation instruments; training courses; a wide selection of publications.
Members of staff contributed to major public inquiries about the [[nuclear industry]] in the UK and supported the UK response to the [[Chernobyl disaster]]. They also participated in the work of the: [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]]; [[International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection]]; [[United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation]]; [[Nuclear Energy Agency]]; various committees of the [[Commission of the European Communities]].
==Transition==
The Health Protection Agency Act 2004 repealed the Radiological Protection Act. On 1 April 2005, NRPB became the Radiation Protection Division of the [[Health Protection Agency]] (HPA). Under the terms of the Health and Social Care Act 2012, the HPA was abolished, and responsibility for radiation protection functions was assigned to appropriate Government authorities in the UK.
==References== {{reflist}}
* ''Radiation Protection: A Memoir of the National Radiological Protection Board. {{ISBN|978-0-85951-586-3}}.'' * ''The NRPB Era. Journal of Radiological Protection, vol 30, pp 85-92 (2010)''
==External links== *[http://www.hpa.org.uk/radiation Health Protection Agency - Radiation] {{nuclear-stub}} [[Category:Medical regulation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Nuclear technology in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct public bodies of the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Oliver Bulman | birth_name = Oliver Meredith Boone Bulman | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1902|5|20}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|1974|2|18|1902|5|20}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = [[University of Cambridge]] | alma_mater = [[Imperial College London|Imperial College]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Lyell Medal]] {{small|(1953)}}
[[Fellow of the Royal Society]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Stubblefield | first1 = J. | doi = 10.1098/rsbm.1975.0004 | title = Oliver Meredith Boone Bulman 20 May 1902 -- 18 February 1974 | journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] | volume = 21 | pages = 175–195| year = 1975 | pmid = | pmc = }} | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Oliver Meredith Boone Bulman''' (20 May 1902 – 18 February 1974) was a [[UK|British]] [[palaeontologist]]. He was [[Woodwardian Professor of Geology]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. ==Early life== Oliver Bulman was born in [[Chelsea, London|Chelsea]] to artist Henry Herbert Bulman and his wife Beatrice Elizabeth Boone. He was the second of three children.{{cite web|author=C. James Stubblefield|title=Bulman, Oliver Meredith Boone (1902–1974), rev. R. B. Rickards|work=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=2004| url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/30874|accessdate=2009-07-26}} ==Education== Bulman went to [[Battersea Grammar School]] in 1910, but wishing to study geology, which the school did not teach, he became an evening, and later day, student at [[Chelsea Polytechnic]]. He gained a London University scholarship in 1920 and went to [[Imperial College London|Imperial College]] to study geology and zoology. He graduated with a first class BSc in geology in 1923. Bulman went on to a PhD degree jointly with [[Cyril James Stubblefield|James Stubblefield]] on the lower [[Palaeozoic]] of the [[Wrekin]] district, of [[Shropshire]] in 1926. Awarded a senior studentship, he worked for a year on [[Permian]] amphibians with [[Walter Frederick Whittard]] and for two years at [[Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge]], where he studied [[Graptolites#Morphology|dendroid graptolites]] under [[Gertrude Lilian Elles]]. Work on the [[Palaeontographical Society]]'s monograph ''British Dendroid Graptolites'' (1927 and 1928) earned him a Cambridge PhD degree in 1928. He then worked as demonstrator at Imperial College and at Cambridge. He became [[Reader (academic rank)|reader]] in [[palaeozoology]] in 1944 and [[Woodwardian Professor of Geology]] in 1955. ==Honours== Bulman was elected an [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] in 1940 and was president of the geology section of the [[British Association]], the [[Palaeontological Association]] (1960–62), the [[Geological Society of London|Geological Society]] (1962–4), and the Palaeontographical Society (1971–4). The Geological Society awarded him the [[Lyell Medal]] in 1953. ==Private life== In 1938 he married Marguerite Fearnsides, daughter of [[William George Fearnsides|William Fearnsides]], the professor of geology at Sheffield. They had a son and three daughters. He died at home in Cambridge in 1974, and was cremated. ==References== {{reflist}} {{GLS Presidents}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bulman, Oliver Meredith Boone}} [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society]] [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1974 deaths]] [[Category:Lyell Medal winners]] [[Category:People educated at Battersea Grammar School]] [[Category:British palaeontologists]] [[Category:Alumni of Imperial College London]] [[Category:Alumni of Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Cambridge]] {{UK-scientist-stub}} {{palaeontologist-stub}}

revision.comment: Replacing Louis_Pasteur,_foto_av_Félix_Nadar_Crisco_edit.jpg with [[File:Louis_Pasteur,_foto_av_Paul_Nadar,_Crisco_edit.jpg]] (by [[commons:User:CommonsDelinker|CommonsDelinker]] because: [[:c:COM:FR|File renamed]]: https://www.getty.edu/art/collection/ob
revision.text:
'''Pasteur's quadrant''' is a classification of scientific research projects that seek fundamental understanding of scientific problems, while also having immediate use for society. [[Louis Pasteur]]'s research is thought to exemplify this type of method, which bridges the gap between "[[basic research|basic]]" and "[[applied research|applied]]" research.{{cite web |url= http://www.fapesp.br/materia/2826 |title= Request for Research Proposals |author= |date= |work= Microsoft Research |publisher= [[Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo|FAPESP]] |access-date= 25 Feb 2015 }} The term was introduced by Donald Stokes in his book, ''Pasteur's Quadrant''.{{cite book |first= Donald E. |last= Stokes |title= Pasteur's Quadrant – Basic Science and Technological Innovation |publisher= [[Brookings Institution]] Press |date= 1997 |url= http://www.brookings.edu/research/books/1997/pasteur |pages= 196 |isbn= 9780815781776 }} ==Applied and basic research== As shown in the following table, scientific research can be classified by whether it advances human knowledge by seeking a fundamental understanding of nature, or whether it is primarily motivated by the need to solve immediate problems. {| class="wikitable" border="0" style="text-align:center" |+ Applied and Basic research ! colspan="2" style="background:white; border-width: 0;" |   ! colspan="2" style="background:white;" | Considerations of use? |- ! colspan="2" style="background:white; border-width: 0;" |   ! No ! Yes |- ! rowspan="2" style="background:white; border-width: 0;"| Quest for fundamental
understanding? ! Yes | [[File:Niels Bohr.jpg |75px |Neils Bohr ]] Pure basic research || [[File:Louis Pasteur, foto av Paul Nadar, Crisco edit.jpg |75px |Louis Pasteur ]] Use-inspired basic research |- ! No | – || [[File:Thomas Edison2.jpg |75px |Thomas Edison ]] Pure applied research |} The result is three distinct classes of research: # Pure basic research, exemplified by the work of [[Niels Bohr]], early 20th century atomic physicist. # Pure applied research, exemplified by the work of [[Thomas Edison]], inventor. # Use-inspired basic research, described here as "Pasteur's Quadrant". Pasteur's quadrant is useful in distinguishing various perspectives within science, engineering and technology. For example, [[Daniel A. Vallero]] and Trevor M. Letcher in their book ''Unraveling Environmental Disasters''.{{cite book |first1= Daniel A. |last1= Vallero |first2= Trevor M. |last2= Letcher |title= Unraveling Environmental Disasters |publisher= [[Elsevier]] Academic Press |date= 2012 |isbn= 9780123970268 |url= http://store.elsevier.com/Unraveling-Environmental-Disasters/isbn-9780123973177/ }} applied the device to disaster preparedness and response. University science programs are concerned with knowledge-building, whereas engineering programs at the same university will apply existing and emerging knowledge to address specific technical problems. Governmental agencies employ the knowledge from both to solve societal problems.{{cn|date=May 2017}} Thus, the [[U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] expects its engineers to apply general scientific principles to design and upgrade flood control systems. This entails selecting the best levee designs for the hydrologic conditions. However, the engineer would also be interested in more basic science to enhance designs in terms of water retention and soil strength. The university scientist is much like Bohr, with the major motivation being new knowledge. The governmental engineer is behaving like Edison, with the greatest interest in utility, and considerably less interest in knowledge for knowledge's sake. The university engineering researcher's interests on the other hand, may fall between Bohr and Edison, looking to enhance both knowledge and utility. It is not likely that many single individuals fall within the Pasteur cell, since both basic and applied science are highly specialized. Thus, modern science and technology employ what might be considered a [[systems engineering]] approach, where the Pasteur cell consists of numerous researchers, professionals and practitioners to optimize solutions. Note that modifications to the quadrant model to more precisely reflect how research and development interact continue to be suggested.{{cite journal |first= John M. |last= Dudley |title= Defending Basic Research |journal= Nature Photonics |volume= 7 |pages= 338–339 |date= 2013 |doi= 10.1038/nphoton.2013.105 |url= http://www.nature.com/nphoton/journal/v7/n5/full/nphoton.2013.105.html |bibcode= 2013NaPho...7..338D }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{sci-stub}} [[Category:Scientific method]]

revision.comment: References
revision.text:
{{more references|date=April 2009}}
'''Nano Seed Priming''' in [[botany]] and [[agriculture]] is a form of [[seed]] planting preparation in which the seeds are pre-soaked in nanoparticle solution.Seeds are considered to be an important part of crop life cycle as it influences the propagation of critical phases like germination and dormancy. Seed priming before sowing is considered to be one of the promising ways to provide value-added solutions to maximize the natural potential of seed to set the plant for maximum yield potential with respect to both quality and quantity. Positive effect on the shoot and root growth of seedlings of wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) when treated with iron-oxide nanoparticles. This innovative cost-effective and user-friendly method of biofortification has proven to increase grain iron deposition upon harvesting. Hence, the intervention of nanotechnology in terms of seed priming could be an economical and user-friendly smart farming approach to increase the nutritive value of the grains in an eco-friendly manner.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Sundaria | first = Naveen | last2 = Singh | first2 = Manoj | last3 = Upreti | first3 = Prateek | last4 = P. Chauhan | first4 = Ravendra | last5 = P. Jaiswal | first5 = J | last6 = Kumar | first6 = Anil | date = 31 May 2018 | title = Seed Priming with Iron Oxide Nanoparticles Triggers Iron Acquisition and Biofortification in Wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) Grains | url = https://doi.org/10.1007/s00344-018-9818-7 | journal = Journal of Plant Growth Regulation | doi = 10.1007/s00344-018-9818-7 | issn = 0721-7595 }}</ref>
Priming is not an extremely widely used method. In general, most kinds of seeds experimented with so far have shown an overall advantage over seeds that are not primed. Many have shown a faster emergence time (the time it takes for seeds to rise above the surface of the soil), a higher emergence rate (the number of seeds that make it to the surface), and better growth, suggesting that the [[head start (positioning)|head-start]] helps them get a good root system down early and grow faster. This method can be useful to farmers because it saves them the money and time spent for fertilizers, re-seeding, and weak plants.
== References == <references />
== External links == * [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/325467181_Seed_Priming_with_Iron_Oxide_Nanoparticles_Triggers_Iron_Acquisition_and_Biofortification_in_Wheat_Triticum_aestivum_L_Grains] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050227011425/http://www.voeding.tno.nl/ProductSheet.cfm?PNR=voe312e Overview of Seed Priming on TNO Quality of Life] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929102858/http://crop.scijournals.org/cgi/content/full/43/6/2135 Priming Winter Wheat on Crop Science] * [http://www.rsnz.org/publish/nzjar/1995/119.pdf Priming '' Papsalum dialatatum '' on The Royal Society of New Zealand]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (pdf file) * [http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/cabi/ssr/2003/00000013/00000004/art00004 Priming mung beans ''(Vigna Radiata)'' on Ingenta Connect]
