revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Simon Dinnerstein | Born = February 16, 1943 | image = | imagesize = | caption = Dinnerstein with his painting, ''At the Still Point'' | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=y|1943|02|16}} | birth_place = Brooklyn, New York, U.S.A. | | nationality = American | field = Painting, Drawing, Printmaking | training = City College of New York, Brooklyn Museum Art School, Hochschule fur Bildende Kunste, Kassel, Germany | movement = Figurative art | works = The Fulbright Triptych, In Sleep, Passage of the Moon | patrons = | awards = Fulbright Fellowship, Germany;
Rome Prize, American Academy in Rome }}'''Simon Dinnerstein''' (born February 16, 1943) is an American artist best known for ''The Fulbright Triptych''. ==Early life== Dinnerstein was born in [[Brownsville, Brooklyn|Brownsville]], [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] in 1943 to pharmacist Louis and homemaker Sarah Dinnerstein. One of two children, his older brother [[Harvey Dinnerstein]] is also an artist.{{cite web|title=Simon and Simone Dinnerstein In Conversation: An Interview with Robin Quivers at the German Consulate of New York|url=http://vimeo.com/37105837}} ==Education and career== Dinnerstein holds a Bachelor of Arts in History from the [[City College of New York]]. He studied painting and drawing at the [[Brooklyn Museum]] Art School with Louis Grebenak, [[David Levine]], and Richard Mayhew.{{cite book|last=Dantzic|first=Cynthia Maris|title=100 New York Painters|date=November 2006|publisher=Schiffer Publishing|isbn=978-0764325434|pages=85}} He was a member of the faculty at the [[New School for Social Research]], [[Parsons School of Design]], and [[New York City Technical College]]. He lectures widely and has lectured at [[Pennsylvania State University]].{{cite web|title=Chronology of Simon Dinnerstein|url=http://www.simondinnerstein.com/chronology.html|accessdate=17 May 2014}} ==Style and influences== Dinnerstein's art is mostly in the [[figurative art|figurative]] style,{{cite news|last=Mertens|first=Richard|title=Essential Realities: Simon Dinnerstein Draws the Essence of Art from the Commonplace|newspaper=The Concord Monitor|date=October 25, 1991}} with [[Folk art|folk]], [[expressionistic]], and [[surrealistic]] influences,{{cite book|last=Messer|first=Thomas M.|title=The Art of Simon Dinnerstein|date=November 1990|publisher=The University of Arkansas Press|location=Foreword|isbn=978-1557281425}}{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Roberta|title=Rediscovered at the Altar of Art|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/12/arts/design/simon-dinnerstein-the-fulbright-triptych-review.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 11, 2011}}{{cite web|last=Hagler|first=Elana|title=Pursuing Humanity: An Interview with Simon Dinnerstein|url=http://paintingperceptions.com/contemporary-realism/pursuing-humanity-an-interview-with-simon-dinnerstein|publisher=Painting Perceptions|accessdate=18 May 2014}} possessing a "[[narrative]]" and "[[psychological]] edge".{{cite news|last=Proctor|first=Roy|title=Exploring the Edge: No Slave to Fashion, Artist Draws Us Into Other States of Mind|newspaper=Richmond Times-Dispatch|date=August 20, 2000}} He uses a variety of media, [[pencils]], [[charcoal]], and [[oil paint]]s. Dinnerstein renders [[still-life]]'s, but most of his work involves [[portrait painting|portraiture]] or [[human figure]]s. He often "paints the figure in unexpected juxtaposition with [[landscape]] or interior elements," of which Dinnerstein says,
What interests me is the ability of [[Degas]], [[Balthus]], [[Lucien Freud]] and [[Antonio Lopez Garcia]]…to deal with the figure…to create art…rich in scale, yet abstract adventurous, experimental…deeply human…a combination of modernism and tradition of skill medium and…a fresh, personal response to the human form in art…Hopefully my work speaks to these issues.
Often the human figures are portrayed against a background of [[hyperreality]], or in dreamy surreal landscapes.{{cite book|last=Slager|first=Daniel, editor|title=The Suspension of Time: Reflections on Simon Dinnerstein and The Fulbright Triptych|date=June 14, 2011|publisher=Milkweed Editions|isbn=978-1571313263}} Light plays an important role in Dinnerstein's work achieving "an inwardness…in the play of light that radiates from the object and renders it mysterious."{{cite book|last=Abramovitch|first=Ilana|title=Jews of Brooklyn|date=2002|publisher=Brandeis University Press|isbn=978-1584650034|pages=169}} or makes "Brooklyn sunlight on an ordinary floor seem supernatural."{{cite book|last=Davenport|first=Guy, essayist|title=The Art of Simon Dinnerstein, Simon Dinnerstein: Paintings and Drawings|date=2000|publisher=Hudson Hills Press|isbn=0965048543}} The use of light contributes to Dinnerstein's paintings being described as "[[magical realism]]".{{cite book|last=Arnheim|first=Rudolph, essayist|title=Simon Dinnerstein: Painting and Drawing|date=2000|publisher=Hudson Hills Press}} In early Dinnerstein works, strong left-right symmetry prevails, although later works are noted for their asymmetry. Dinnerstein draws on diverse sources for inspiration: Northern European art ([[Albrecht Dürer]], [[Hieronymus Bosch]]{{cite web|title=Triptych: An Evening of Painting and Music: Simon Dinnerstein & Robert Sirota|url=http://vimeo.com/92970548|accessdate=17 May 2014}}), Mexican art ([[Frida Kahlo]], [[Diego Rivera]]{{cite news|last=McLeod|first=Deborah|title=Bodies of Work: From Visceral Portraits to Romanticized Nymphs, Simon Dinnerstein's Retrospective at the Marsh Gallery Shows a Stylistic Niche through Every Turn of the Artist's Evolution |url=http://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/from-visceral-portraits-to-romanticized-nymphs-simon-dinnersteins-retrospective-at-the-marsh-gallery-shows-a-stylistic-niche-through-every/Content?oid=1386808 |accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=Richmond Style Weekly|date=September 1, 2000}}), as well as literature ([[D. H. Lawrence]], [[August Strindberg]]{{cite journal|last=Dinnerstein|first=Simon|title=Looking At One's Own Artwork|journal=American Artist|date=April 1986}}). , and film ([[Ingmar Bergman]], [[Alfred Hitchcock]]). ==''The Fulbright Triptych''== Dinnerstein's most notable painting, ''The [[Fulbright]] Triptych'', was started in [[Germany]] in 1971 while he served as a [[Fulbright Scholar]] in Graphics. It was completed in 1974. A largely autobiographical work,{{cite book|last=Boime|first=Albert|title=The Art of Simon Dinnerstein|date=November 1990|publisher=The University of Arkansas Press|isbn=978-1557281425}} it combines stark realism with American figurative tradition to produce a secular rendering of the usually religious form, the [[triptych]]. Writer [[Jonathan Lethem]] commented: "Simon Dinnerstein's 'The Fulbright Triptych' is one of those singular and astonishing works of art which seem to imply a description of the whole world merely by insisting on a scrupulous gaze at one perfect instant." The oil-on-wood painting consists of three panels approximately 14 feet wide, depicting a graphic artist's studio.{{cite web|last=Dinnerstein|first=Simon|title=The Fulbright Triptych|url=http://www.simondinnerstein.com/the_fulbright_triptych.html|accessdate=17 May 2014}} Three figures, representing the Dinnerstein family, occupy the outer panels. The central panel consists of the artist's desk, engraving tools, a copper disk of the commissioned Fulbright engraving project, and an outward view in perspective of Hessisch Lichtenau (near to [[Kassel]]).{{cite news|last=Russell|first=John|title=In Dinnerstein's Painting, An Echo Chamber|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 8, 1975}} Plants, photographs, old master's paintings, children's grade school writing, and an exit visa from Russia, appear tacked to the wall of the studio.{{cite journal|last=André|first=Michael|title=Simon Dinnerstein (Staempfli)|journal=Art News|date=March 1975}} The "Triptych" is noted for its symmetry, meticulous detail, mixture of textures, and sense of space. Widely praised, with each viewer bringing a different sensibility and interpretation of the work, the painting is the subject of numerous essays, articles, and books, including "The Suspension of Time: Reflections of Simon Dinnerstein's The Fulbright Triptych" edited by Daniel Slager, published 2011. Among the many who have commented on the painting are art critic [[John Russell (art critic)|John Russell]], [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] director [[Thomas M. Messer]], art historian [[Albert Boime]], artist [[George Tooker]], writer [[Anthony Doerr]], composer [[George Crumb]], poet [[Dan Beachy-Quick]], actor [[John Turturro]], and [[Pulitzer Prize]] winner [[Jhumpa Lahiri]]. ==Personal life== In 1965, Dinnerstein married Renée Sudler, a noted educational consultant. Renée Dinnerstein is the author of the book "Choice Time: How to Deepen Learning Through Inquiry and Play, PreK-2" published in August 2016.{{cite web|title=Author Bio: Renee Dinnerstein|url=http://www.heinemann.com/authors/100093.aspx|publisher=Heinemann Publishing, of Houghton, Mifflin, Harcourt|accessdate=10 September 2016}} She runs the popular blog, [http://investigatingchoicetime.com/ Investigating Choice Time: Inquiry, Exploration and Play].{{cite web|title=About Renée Dinnerstein|url=http://investigatingchoicetime.com/about/|publisher=Investigating Choice Time: Inquiry, Exploration, and Play|accessdate=17 May 2014}} They have a daughter, [[Simone Dinnerstein]], the virtuoso concert pianist. Both wife and daughter (as an infant) figure prominently in "The Fulbright Triptych" as well as other works. Dinnerstein resides in Brooklyn, where, in addition to practicing his art, he teaches classes on art history and appreciation. ==Videos and podcasts== *Simone Dinnerstein and Simon Dinnerstein In Conversation: An Interview with [[Robin Quivers]] at Consulate General of Germany, 2011{{cite web|url=http://vimeo.com/37105837|title=• Simone Dinnerstein • Simon Dinnerstein • In Conversation on Vimeo|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2016}} *Triptych: An Evening of Painting and Music (Simon Dinnerstein, The Fulbright Triptych and Robert Sirota, "Triptych", performed by the Chiara String Quartet){{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/92970548|title=TRIPTYCH: AN EVENING OF PAINTING AND MUSIC: SIMON DINNERSTEIN & ROBERT SIROTA|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2016}} *Simon Dinnerstein Exhibit at the Tenri Gallery: A Walk Through with [[Francis Cunningham (painter)|Francis Cunningham]], 2011{{YouTube|eukDmYhfYI8}} *Simon Dinnerstein and The Fulbright Triptych, audiocast interview with James McElhinney, Huffington Post, April 1, 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.nccsc.net/webcasts/audiocasts/simon-dinnerstein|title=Simon Dinnerstein|publisher=|accessdate=30 October 2016}} *“Simone Dinnerstein and Simon Dinnerstein: A Conversation on the Mysteries of Art and Family, 2018 ”{{cite web |title=“Simone Dinnerstein and Simon Dinnerstein: A Conversation on the Mysteries of Art and Family,” revision.text:
'''Social interface''' is a concept from [[social science]] (particularly, [[media ecology (Marshall McLuhan) and sociology of technology]]).
It can be approached from a theoretical or a practical perspective.
As a concept of social interface theory, social interface is defined by [[Norman Long (anthropologist) | Norman Long]] (1989, 2001). In 2001 his revised definition was:
{{cquote|"a social interface is a critical point of intersection between different [[lifeworld]]s, [[social field]]s or levels of [[social organization]], where [[social discontinuity|social discontinuities]] based upon discrepancies in values, interests, knowledges and power, are most likely to be located."<ref name=long>For old 1989 definition, see Long, Norman, ed. 1989. Encounters at the Interface: a Perspective in Social Discontinuities in Rural Development, Wageningse Sociologische Studies 27. Wageningen: Wageningen Agricultural University. For new 2001 definition, see [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y94nwmAgkI4C&pg=PA243&dq=%22Social+interface%22&as_brr=3&ei=9VyGSMHyMI6UiAHnmNDcAw&sig=ACfU3U0JzvkhPV5yukxOcgG7WF8sIlvU0gGoogle Print, p.243] in Norman Long, ''Development Sociology: Actor Perspectives'', Routledge, 2001, {{ISBN|0-415-23535-9}}, </ref>}}
In other words, interfaces are the areas in which social friction can be experienced and where [[technology diffusion|diffusion of new technology]] is leading to structural discontinuities (which can be both positive or negative), the interface is where they will occur. Long continues to say that:
{{cquote|" ... the concept implies face-to-face encounters between individuals or social units representing different interests and backed by different resources."<ref name=long/>}}
Identifying these interfaces and analyzing their effects shows how they are changed by everyday life, and how in return everyday life is changed by the interfaces.<ref>Long, N. 1992. From paradigm lost to paradigm regained; the case of actor-oriented sociology of development. Pages 16-43 in N. Long and A. Long, editors. Battlefields of knowledge: the interlocking of theory and practice in social research and development. Routledge, New York, New York, USA.</ref><ref>Arce, A., and N. Long. 1992. The dynamics of knowledge: interfaces between bureaucrats and peasants. Pages 211-245 in N. Long and A. Long, editors. Battlefields of knowledge: the interlocking of theory and practice in social research and development. Routledge, London, UK.</ref><ref>Douthwaite, B., N. C. de Haan, V. Manyong, and D. Keatinge. 2001. Blending "hard" and "soft" science: the "follow-the-technology" approach to catalyzing and evaluating technology change. Conservation Ecology 5(2): 13. [online] URL: http://www.consecol.org/vol5/iss2/art13/ </ref>
As practical concept of [[social interface design]], social interface is seen in the studies of [[human-computer interaction]] (in particular, its [[computer interface]] aspect). The basic thesis is that where a computer interface is more akin to another human, it can facilitate correct responses from users during human-to-computer interaction. Software that can provide such humanizing cues often does it by creating interface with human-like quality (such as giving recognizable [[gender]] to a [[software agent]]).<ref>Tourangeau R.; Couper M.P.; Steiger D.M., '' Humanizing self-administered surveys: experiments on social presence in web and IVR surveys'', Computers in Human Behavior, Volume 19, Number 1, January 2003 , pp. 1-24(24), [http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/els/07475632/2003/00000019/00000001/art00032]</ref> Studies are often concerned with how should such agents (like the [[Microsoft Agent]]) be designed to make them more appealing (is having [[facial expression]]s efficient, should the agent be [[anthropomorphic]], and so on). <ref>Michael A. Cusumano, Richard W. Selby, ''Microsoft Secrets: How the World's Most Powerful Software Company Creates Technology, Shakes Markets and Manages People''. Simon and Schuster, 1998, {{ISBN|0-684-85531-3}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=GixEgGs5qXcC&pg=PA178&dq=%22Social+interface%22&lr=&as_brr=3&ei=U72ESNnMNIHsiQHKtO3jAg&sig=ACfU3U3qf7_iTQNRwNyWc9znyPOY0Qu5_Q Google Print, p.178]</ref>
==See also== * [[Interactivity]]
==Notes== <!--See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref(erences/)> tags--> {{Reflist}} 7. Turnbull, B. E. (1998). Street children and their helpers: a social interface analysis (Doctoral dissertation, University of Sussex).
==External links== * [http://www.mfeldstein.com/a_different_take_on_social_interfaces/ Michael Feldstein: "A Different Take on Social Interfaces"] * [http://www.usabilityviews.com/uv010616.html social interface theory]
